A belt capable of transporting electric charge is connected by a motor to a spherical conducting surface of radius <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The motor and conducting surface are separated by an insulating stand. When the motor is turned on for a time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, an unknown amount of charge <math alttext="uppercase Q sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is transferred onto the sphere. After the sphere has been charged, an uncharged conducting ball of radius <math alttext="lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hanging from a nonconducting string is brought close to, but not touching, the sphere. The sphere and ball then touch, and a short time later the ball hangs at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> relative to the vertical. The height of the ball is adjusted such that the center of the ball and the sphere are at the same vertical height, as shown. The students measure the radii of the sphere and ball and determine that <math alttext="uppercase R equals 10 times lowercase r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and correctly conclude that after the ball and sphere touch, the charge remaining on the conducting sphere <math alttext="uppercase Q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the charge on the ball <math alttext="lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are related by the expression <math alttext="uppercase Q equals 10 times lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The rate <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at which charge is transferred onto the sphere when the motor is turned on is approximately constant for 8 seconds of charging. The students are expected to experimentally determine <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment typically found in a high school physics lab. (a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.
